review.title: A logic for reasoning about ambiguity
review.abstract: Standard models of multi-agent modal logic do not capture the fact that information is often \emph{ambiguous}, and may be interpreted in different ways by different agents. We propose a framework that can model this, and consider different semantics that capture different assumptions about the agents' beliefs regarding whether or not there is ambiguity. We examine the expressive power of logics of ambiguity compared to logics that cannot model ambiguity, with respect to the different semantics that we propose.

sections.text: We want a logic in which the players use a fixed common language, but each player can interpret formulas in the language differently. sections.heading: 2.3 Prior-generated beliefs
sections.text: One assumption that we do not necessarily make, but want to examine in this context, is the general-prior assumption. The general-prior assumption is an instance of a more general assumption that beliefs are generated from a previous state that we are now defining. Intuition is that players start with a prior probability; they then update the previous one in light of their information. Player i's information is captured by their partition.

sections.heading: 2.4 Capturing ambiguity
sections.text: We use epistemic probability structures to give meaning to formulas. Since primitive suggestions are interpreted relative to the players, we must allow the interpretation of any formula that also depends on the players. Exactly, how we do this depends on what further assumptions we make about the interpretations of the other player. There are many assumptions that could be made. The first approach is suitable for situations where players can interpret statements differently, but it does not occur to them that there is any other way to interpret the statement. Thus, in this model, if there is a public announcement, all players think that their interpretation of the announcement is general knowledge.

sections.heading: 3 Common interpretations suffice
sections.text: In this section, we show in a sense that we do not need structures with ambiguity. Specifically, we show that the same formulas are valid in common structures of interpretation as in structures that do not have a common interpretation, no matter what semantics we use, even if we have ambiguity about the information structures. To clarify this, we need some notations. Fix a non-empty, countable compilation of primitive suggestions, and let M (both) be the structures that satisfy A1-A4 and are defined by some non-empty subclauses.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: We defined a logic for thinking about ambiguity and then showed that we do not need structures with ambiguity in two ways: (1) the same axioms record whether we have ambiguity or not, and (2) we can use richer language to talk about ambiguity while giving all formulas an unambitious interpretation. (1) So why do we bother using structures with ambiguity? Perhaps the main reason for this is that it enables us to describe the situation from the agent's point of view. For example, when we are dealing with the most extreme extent, an agent does not realize that there are other interpretations than the one he uses. Thus, the simpler language captures the agents "assertions more directly. Similarly, a structure with ambiguity could describe more accurately than a structure with a common interpretation. We therefore believe that structures with ambiguity will prove useful.
